importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of publication of the article highlighting the growing reliance on Indigenous knowledge in Pakistan's climate resilience efforts.
The launch date of the $37 million GLOF-II project, which aimed to improve early warning systems in Gilgit-Baltistan but failed to gain community trust or operational effectiveness.
The year the World Bank reported Pakistan's temperature rise since the 1950s, establishing the national context of climate vulnerability.
The start of a period during which Pakistan experienced nearly 90 glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs) between 2019 and 2022, underscoring the increasing frequency of climate-related disasters.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of intensified climate change impacts in Pakistan, marked by rising temperatures, glacier melt, and recurrent GLOFs, which have increased public and governmental focus on climate adaptation.
The timeframe during which the GLOF-II project was initiated and evaluated, revealing systemic failures in early warning system implementation and community trust.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including traditional signs like unusual animal behavior, loud noises, and signal fires or gunfire, is being used by local communities in Gilgit-Baltistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

Despite significant investments in early warning systems (EWS), such as the $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017, communities in northern Pakistan have shown little trust in these systems due to frequent failures, lack of maintenance, and poor communication.
Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan and Ghizer rely on human-based alert systems—passed down through generations—especially when technological systems fail or malfunction.

The combination of climate change (including rising temperatures and reduced snowfall) and weak institutional capacity has intensified the frequency and severity of GLOFs, posing a serious threat to lives and livelihoods in mountainous regions.

The lack of trust in EWS has led to communities depending on individuals like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, who use traditional methods to warn others, often saving lives in the absence of working technology.

The government's recognition of these heroes—such as awarding $28,000 each to shepherds who saved lives—shows the value placed on human-based, Indigenous knowledge in climate adaptation despite technological shortcomings.
Pakistan, though contributing less than 1% of global emissions, ranks among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations due to its geography and climate patterns.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who survived a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) and used Indigenous knowledge to alert villagers, saving lives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His firsthand experience illustrates the effectiveness of Indigenous knowledge in responding to climate-related disasters when formal systems fail.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who used traditional warning signs and gunfire signals to alert villagers during a flash flood.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents a broader pattern of community-based, human-driven early warning systems that have proven effective despite technological system failures.

namedEntities.name: Ghizer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in northern Pakistan’s Gilgit-Baltistan where many Indigenous knowledge-based responses to GLOFs have occurred.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ghizer is a key location where Indigenous practices are actively used due to high glacial activity and limited access to formal early warning systems.

namedEntities.name: Skardu Valley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in Gilgit-Baltistan where residents rely on traditional warning methods due to the failure or inaccessibility of EWS technology.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It exemplifies the regional context in which Indigenous knowledge is both necessary and effective for disaster preparedness.

namedEntities.name: Gilgit-Baltistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in northern Pakistan home to over 13,000 glaciers and high vulnerability to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary region affected by climate change and where Indigenous knowledge systems are being used in response to recurring GLOFs.

namedEntities.name: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A province in Pakistan that is also part of the climate-vulnerable region and includes areas affected by GLOFs and early warning system failures.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It expands the geographic scope of climate vulnerability and early warning system challenges beyond Gilgit-Baltistan.

namedEntities.name: NDMA (National Disaster Management Authority)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Pakistan government body responsible for monitoring and responding to climate disasters like GLOFs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has projected reduced snowfall and glacier retreat due to climate change, contributing to the increased risk of GLOFs, and has implemented early warning systems with limited success.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan Meteorological Department
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The body responsible for monitoring and transmitting real-time data from early warning systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It receives real-time data from sensors, but communication gaps and lack of integration with local communities limit effectiveness.

namedEntities.name: GLOF (Glacial Lake Outburst Flood)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A climate-related disaster caused by the sudden release of water from a glacial lake, common in northern Pakistan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the central climate hazard discussed in the article and the reason for reliance on Indigenous knowledge and traditional warning systems.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international institution that has assessed Pakistan’s climate vulnerability, citing a 1.3°C temperature rise since the 1950s.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides a global context for Pakistan’s climate vulnerability, reinforcing the urgency of adaptation strategies like Indigenous knowledge systems.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It offers a global perspective on why EWS failures occur, including in Pakistan, and emphasizes the need for community trust and capacity building.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It exemplifies the government’s technological investment, which has failed to gain community trust and has been undermined by poor implementation and maintenance.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national leader who awarded $28,000 to shepherds for saving lives during GLOF events.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It highlights the recognition of Indigenous knowledge agents as heroes, signaling a shift toward valuing community-based resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly Gilgit-Baltistan and Ghizer, communities are increasingly relying on Indigenous knowledge—such as observing animal behavior, unusual weather patterns, and using traditional signals like gunfire or fire—to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite government investments in early warning systems (EWS), such as the $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017, these systems have failed to gain trust due to malfunctioning equipment, lack of maintenance, and poor communication with local populations. Residents have reported that warnings are often issued by local shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, who use time-tested, human-based methods that have successfully saved lives. The article underscores Pakistan’s status as one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations, with rising temperatures and glacier melt accelerating disaster frequency. It highlights a broader global challenge: that technology alone cannot ensure safety without community trust, cultural relevance, and effective implementation. As Pakistan faces more frequent and severe GLOFs, the integration of Indigenous knowledge into climate adaptation strategies is emerging as a vital, proven, and culturally grounded solution.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
